name: TODO tracker
prompt:
Step 1: Scan the entire codebase for TODO, FIXME, HACK, XXX, and WORKAROUND comments:
  grep -rn "TODO\|FIXME\|HACK\|XXX\|WORKAROUND" --include="*.ts" --include="*.tsx" --include="*.js" --include="*.jsx" --include="*.py" --include="*.go" --include="*.rs" --include="*.rb" . | grep -v node_modules | grep -v dist | grep -v .git

Step 2: Read the previous scan results from .9to5/todo-inventory.md if it exists.

Step 3: Compare current scan to previous:
  - Identify NEW todos added since last scan
  - Identify RESOLVED todos that were removed
  - Count total by category (TODO, FIXME, HACK, etc.)

Step 4: Generate an updated inventory report:
  - Total count by type
  - New additions this week (with file:line and the comment text)
  - Resolved since last scan
  - Oldest TODOs (by git blame date) — flag anything older than 3 months
  - Files with the highest concentration of TODOs

Step 5: Write the updated inventory to .9to5/todo-inventory.md
  Commit it with message "chore: update TODO inventory [automated]"

Step 6: Output a summary to stdout.
system_prompt: You are a codebase hygiene tracker. Be factual and concise. Don't editorialize about whether TODOs are good or bad — just track them. Flag anything older than 3 months as stale.
